Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2008 02:52PM donnajrn wrote: I know this decision is very confusing.  Every doc seems to have a different idea about the necessity of doing radiation.  My radiation oncologist told me that the good candidates to skip rads were:     1. small size       2. good margins       3. not grade 3         and 4. not really young (she initially said  old---til I gave her the look)(I am 61)................so, although I had 4 out of 4............she  gave  me a grade of  2.5 cause of necrosis  and  felt I was closer to 3).....which endup up at 3 out of 4.............the tumor board at the hospital said I should have radiation, so I did.  I agree with Sandy.  I wanted to do everything I could to get rid of this.  I have also finished my treatments and had no big problems, just little ones easily managed.   (redness, fatigue). Good luck on your decision. Donna

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2008 01:16PM donnajrn wrote: I had a lumpectomy in May and did not use a different bra.  I had a nice one that was not underwire that I wore for the first several days.(day and night)  It was nice cause it supported  the ice pack.  I used the ice pack the hospital gave me with the stereotactic biopsy (kept it), but found a baggie filled with peas worked great. Just kept changing them out. I am still wearing the same bras I wore preop.  I did not have a node taken out, but my friend who is following in my footsteps did, and she wore the same bras.  One thing her surgeon suggested for her, she mentioned it hurt to shower---guess pulling on the node incision.  He suggested wearing a bra when  you shower.  If you want an all cotton bra with a front closure....go to WalMart, they have some that are reasonable and would probably work nicely for you. Although some of your tissue is removed a "seroma" will form that is just fluid.  I had that for about 5 weeks--so I did not look any different.  It disappeared after 5 weeks, and I look just the same as preop.  It all depends on your breast size---the smaller you are, the more you will notice it.  Also, I did not have a dressing on my incision, just a surgical glue. Good luck with your surgery. Donna

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2008 06:57AM donnajrn wrote: Hi, Like you I think I got callouses on my fingers for googling everything when I found out I had DCIS.  I think I almost did too much.  I had my surgery in May and right now am halfway through radiation.  I think you might benefit from Dr Susan Love's book  The Breast Book, a coworker and fellow survivor recommended it to me and it has become my major resource.  Another coworker had her surgery for LCIS last week.  Our surgeon recommended she shower with a bra on because she was complaining about discomfort then.  Think a person could buy some of the cotton bras from WalMart for that.  The internet is a great resource for us.  I found the Johns Hopkins site for some questions.  I read about curcumin that someone said looks like the Asian aspirin.  There are studies going on at some major cancer centers, it is a major antioxident and looks like it does some great things.  I bought some online and will restart it after I finish my radiation. (my radiation oncologist recommended I not take it during my treatment. Looks like I will start Tamoxifin next month.  Am not looking forward to it at all because of the potential hot flashes, but I will do whatever it takes. Take care, Donna

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2011 04:23AM donnajrn wrote: Hi ladies, what an awesome group.  I have been a nurse since....forever...and still working full time.  I was diagnosed with DCIS 3 1/2 years ago had lumpectomy and radiation.  I have been on tamoxifen for 3 years and was ready to try a trial off of it because of side effects....then I had my routine mammogram!  This (after mammo, biopsy and MRI) showed LCIS..which is, not cancer..but then I say, why does it have cancer in the name!  This just means I am at a higher risk for developing invasive cancer in the future.  I said to someone, a lot of good the tamoxifen did me...but she said: maybe it did work...makes me think.  I also did research when I had my first surgery and read about curcumin....and been taking that for about 3 years also.  So..I am scheduled for surgery next month (excisional biopsy--not lumpectomy cause this is not cancer-but same type of surgery) and depending upon that result.............will either have close follow-ups or go the BMX route.......Here I go again! Donna
